title: Backpressure signaling
description: Signal backpressure from chunk managers to ingesters when ingestion is too fast.
notes:
Go's blocking semantics provide basic backpressure for free — if chunk Append blocks, the ingester goroutine stops reading from the network, TCP buffers fill, and the sender slows down.

This issue covers explicit backpressure beyond the implicit kind:
- Return HTTP 429 / RELP NACK instead of just being slow
- Drop low-priority messages under load instead of blocking everything
- Observable metrics on queue depth and backpressure events
- Configurable buffer limits before implicit backpressure kicks in

title: Logfmt index
description:
Dedicated logfmt indexer that assumes the entire line is logfmt format.

Unlike the generic KV index (which is conservative to avoid false positives on arbitrary text), this indexer can use a proper logfmt parser that handles:
- Hyphenated keys (pod-name=api-server, container-id=abc123)
- Bare/boolean keys (active without = means true)
- Escape sequences in quoted values (msg="has \"quotes\"")
- Colons and other special characters in keys (service:name=api)

Consider using go-logfmt/logfmt as the parser. The indexer should produce the same index format as the KV index (key=value pairs) so existing query infrastructure works unchanged.

Implement a retention policy system for stores. A policy defines when chunks should be deleted — by age (TTL) or by total store size (keep last N bytes). A background goroutine periodically evaluates policies and removes expired/excess chunks.

title: User registration and login
description: Basic user accounts with email/password registration, login, and session management.
notes:
Keep it simple: username + bcrypt password, SQLite storage.

Registration: username + password → bcrypt hash → store in SQLite.
Login: verify hash → issue JWT (short-lived access token + longer-lived refresh token).
Auth: Authorization header with bearer JWT → verify signature → extract user.
Password change: authenticated user provides old password + new password → verify old → update hash.

No OAuth, no email verification. Those can be layered on later.

JWT plays well with the distributed architecture (yjw5) — headless agents and remote instances can verify tokens without hitting a central session store.

Bootstrap: If no users exist, the UI shows a first-time setup screen to create the initial admin account. Once created, the setup screen disappears and normal login takes over. Must work without CLI access (Docker containers).

title: API authentication (JWT/session tokens)
description:
Authenticate API requests via JWT. Single token (7-day default) verified by signature (no server-side session lookup). Protect endpoints that require a logged-in user. Connect RPC middleware to extract and validate the token on each request.

Token duration is adjustable via the server config in the KV settings store. JWT signing secret is auto-generated during bootstrap and persisted in the KV store so tokens survive backend restarts.

No refresh tokens — simplified to a single long-lived token per the decision in 54xw.

title: Migrate retention sweeps to shared scheduler
description: Retention currently runs as a per-store goroutine with time.Ticker at a hardcoded 1-minute interval. This should be migrated to the shared Scheduler so retention jobs are visible alongside cron rotation jobs, and the interval becomes configurable via cron expressions rather than hardcoded.

title: Migrate index builds and other ad-hoc tasks to shared scheduler
description:
Index builds are currently managed as unbounded goroutines tracked by indexWg/indexCtx in the orchestrator. These should be migrated to the shared Scheduler using gocron's OneTimeJob support, which would make them visible in ScheduledJobs(), provide built-in concurrency limiting via WithLimitConcurrentJobs, and consolidate shutdown handling.

Beyond index builds, audit the orchestrator for any other ad-hoc goroutine-managed work that could benefit from moving to the scheduler. Candidates might include ingester lifecycle management or any future background tasks.

The Scheduler wrapper will need a new RunOnce method backed by OneTimeJob(OneTimeJobStartImmediately()).

title: Relative time ranges (last=5m) instead of absolute start/end

title: Structural JSON index (GIN-style path/containment queries)
notes:
The current JSON extractor flattens shallow JSON into key=value pairs with dot-separated paths. This works for flat/simple JSON logs but falls short for deeply nested structures, arrays of objects, and keys that contain dots.

A proper structural JSON index would support:
- Arrays of objects: spans[*].attributes.db.statement
- Deep nesting beyond 4 levels
- Distinguishing dotted keys (service.name as single key) from nested paths
- Containment queries (does this record's JSON contain this sub-structure)
- Path existence queries

Conceptually similar to PostgreSQL's GIN index for JSONB. Would likely need a new index format and query syntax extensions.

title: RELP ingester (reliable syslog transport)

RELP provides reliable delivery over TCP with transaction-based acknowledgements, preventing message loss during network issues or receiver restarts. Commonly used in enterprise syslog infrastructure as a more reliable alternative to plain TCP/UDP syslog.

title: File tail ingester (local log file watching)
description:
Native file tailing ingester for watching local log files without requiring external forwarders.

Implementation details:
- Glob patterns for file discovery (param: paths, comma-separated, e.g. /var/log/*.log,/opt/app/logs/*.log)
- fsnotify as primary change detection (both directory-level for new files and file-level for content)
- Slow background poll as safety net for edge cases (param: poll_interval, default 30s, 0 to disable)
- Position bookmarking in <datadir>/state/tail/<ingester_id>.json, persisted across restarts
- Log rotation detection: inode tracking, truncation detection (file shrinks)
- Re-evaluation of glob patterns for new/removed files via fsnotify on parent directories
- Line-delimited: supports both \n and \r\n, each line = one IngestMessage
- SourceTS left as zero (separate issue gastrolog-1n9u handles extraction from content)
- Params: paths (required), poll_interval (default 30s)
acceptance:
- Watches files matching glob patterns and emits one IngestMessage per line
- Supports both \n and \r\n line endings
- Uses fsnotify for primary change detection (new files and content changes)
- Falls back to configurable poll interval as safety net
- Persists file positions in <datadir>/state/tail/<ingester_id>.json
- Resumes from last position after restart
- Detects log rotation (inode change, file truncation) and handles gracefully
- Discovers new files matching globs and stops tracking removed files
- Registered as ingester type 'tail' with factory pattern
notes:
Native file tailing ingester for watching local log files without requiring external forwarders like rsyslog or Promtail. Should support:
- Glob patterns for file discovery (e.g., /var/log/*.log)
- Position bookmarking across restarts
- Log rotation detection (inode tracking, truncation detection)

close_reason: Implemented tail ingester with fsnotify + doublestar glob support, bookmark persistence, rotation/truncation detection, and frontend configuration UI.

description: Features for handling logs that don't fit the simple one-line-per-record model: multi-line events (stack traces, continuation lines), extracting timestamps from message content when the envelope lacks them, and configurable parsing for structured field extraction. Enables better indexing and querying of real-world log formats.

title: Multi-line log events: detect and group stack traces and continuation lines
description: Detect and group multi-line log events into single logical records. Stack traces (e.g. Java, Python, Go), indented continuation lines, and similar patterns span multiple physical lines but represent one event. Current ingestion treats each line as a separate record. Need heuristics or configurable patterns to recognize continuation lines (e.g. lines starting with 'at ', 'Caused by:', whitespace indent) and merge them into one record. Optionally support post-hoc grouping for already-ingested data.

title: Extract SourceTS from log message content when not in envelope
description: When the log envelope (e.g. syslog header, Docker JSON) lacks a timestamp, attempt to extract SourceTS from the message body. Many log formats embed timestamps in the first line (e.g. '2024-01-15 10:30:45 ERROR ...', RFC3339 in JSON). Add configurable parsing (regex, format hints) to extract a timestamp and set SourceTS. Falls back to zero when extraction fails. Complements the SourceTS index work — more records can participate in source-time queries if we can extract timestamps from content.
close_reason: Already implemented by the Timestamp digester

title: Separate certificate storage from TLS server settings in config store
description:
PutTLSConfig and GetTLSConfig on the Store interface conflate two unrelated concerns: certificate data (PEM content, file paths) stored in the tls_certificates table, and TLS server settings (enabled, redirect, default_cert) stored in the settings table as part of server config JSON. This coupling causes a non-atomicity issue — PutTLSConfig writes server settings first, then certs in a separate transaction — and is redundant with PutServerConfig which already manages TLS server settings through its own read-modify-write path.

Replace GetTLSConfig/PutTLSConfig with dedicated certificate CRUD methods on the Store interface (e.g. ListCertificates, GetCertificate, PutCertificate, DeleteCertificate). TLS server settings stay exclusively in server config. The API layer's PutCertificate calls both independently: save the cert, then update server config if set_as_default is set.

title: File store silently recreates missing data directory on startup
description:
## Problem

When a file store's data directory is missing (deleted, `/tmp` cleanup, disk failure), the chunk manager silently recreates it via `os.MkdirAll` and starts with zero chunks. The server comes up normally with no warning, no error, and no indication that an entire store's worth of log data has been lost.

This is dangerous because:
- An admin would have no way to detect the data loss without manually checking record counts
- `/tmp`-based stores are especially vulnerable to OS cleanup
- Accidental `rm -rf` or disk issues become invisible

## Expected Behavior

On startup, if a file store's directory is missing or empty (no chunk subdirectories) but the store has been previously configured (i.e., it's not a brand-new store being created for the first time), gastrolog should:

1. Log a prominent warning (e.g., `WARN store "foo" data directory was missing or empty, recreated with 0 chunks`)
2. Optionally refuse to start (configurable) if data loss is detected

## Location

- `backend/internal/chunk/file/manager.go` — `NewManager` calls `os.MkdirAll` unconditionally at line ~139
- `backend/internal/orchestrator/factory.go` — `ApplyConfig` creates chunk managers during startup

## Possible Approaches

- Before `MkdirAll`, check if the directory already exists. If it doesn't, set a flag. After `loadExisting()`, if the flag is set and zero chunks were found, log a warning.
- Alternatively, track "expected chunk count" in the config store and compare on startup.

title: Show active jobs in an inspector tab
description: Add an inspector tab that displays currently running and recently completed jobs (reindex, compact, merge, clone, migrate, etc.). Updates should be push-based (SSE or WebSocket) rather than relying on the 10-second polling interval, which is guaranteed to miss most short-lived job runs.

title: Adopt surrogate primary keys across all persistent entities
description: As the database grows, finding suitable natural candidate keys becomes increasingly difficult and fragile. We should introduce surrogate primary keys for all persistent entities (config stores, filters, policies, ingesters, users, etc.). This requires deciding on a key format (auto-increment, UUIDv7, ULID, nanoid, etc.) and migrating existing tables. Natural IDs would become unique constraints rather than primary keys.

title: Remove microsecond timestamp precision option — standardize on nanoseconds
description: The system currently supports both microsecond and nanosecond timestamp precision as a configurable option. Simplify by standardizing on nanosecond precision everywhere. This affects timestamp storage, display formatting, query parsing, and any FE/BE configuration that exposes the precision choice. Remove the microsecond option and any related branching logic. The system is still in development, so no need to migrate existing log files — just change the format and start fresh.

title: First-time setup wizard
description:
When gastrolog starts with no configuration (fresh install), guide the user through initial setup via a step-by-step wizard. Should cover essentials like creating the first store, configuring an ingester, and any other baseline settings needed to start collecting logs. The wizard should be skippable and not reappear once setup is complete.

As an alternative to the wizard, a -bootstrap flag should start gastrolog with a sensible default configuration (in-memory store + chatterbox ingester), bypassing the wizard entirely. This is the current behavior when no config exists, just made explicit via a flag.

title: Frontend silently swallows 401 errors — no global auth error handling
description:
After deleting the data directory and restarting, the frontend still holds an old JWT token in localStorage (signed with the now-gone secret). API calls fail with Unauthenticated but the user is never redirected to login — they just see empty data.

Root causes:

1. The Connect RPC transport has no global error interceptor for 401/Unauthenticated responses. Only search and follow errors are caught in App.tsx; all other hooks (config, stores, ingesters) silently fail.

2. useFollow treats 401 as a transient error and enters a reconnect loop instead of redirecting to login.

3. The router's beforeLoad guard only checks that a token exists in localStorage, not that it's valid.

Fix: add a global error interceptor at the transport layer (in client.ts) that catches Code.Unauthenticated, clears the token, and redirects to /login. Remove the per-hook 401 handling in App.tsx once the global interceptor is in place.

title: Consolidate orchestrator store registries into a Store struct
description:
The orchestrator currently maintains three parallel maps (chunks, indexes, queries) keyed by store ID, with the invariant that every store ID must exist in all three. This is maintained by careful code in reconfig.go and factory.go but isn't structurally enforced.

Introduce a lightweight Store type:

```go
type Store struct {
    ID      string
    Chunks  chunk.ChunkManager
    Indexes index.IndexManager
    Query   *query.Engine
    Enabled bool
}
```

Replace the three parallel maps with a single `map[string]*Store`.

## What moves into Store

Anything that operates on a single store's triplet:

- **Append + seal detection + index triggering** — currently spread across ingest.go, becomes `store.Append(rec)` with seal-detect-then-index as the Store's responsibility
- **Factory wiring** — creating the CM/IM/QE triplet from a StoreConfig becomes a Store constructor
- **Enable/disable** toggling
- **Per-store shutdown** — close CM, wait for index builds

## What stays in the orchestrator

Anything that's cross-store coordination:

- The ingest channel and loop
- Filter routing (`FilterSet.Match` → which stores get a message)
- Ingester lifecycle
- The store registry itself (add/remove/rename/list)

## Non-goals

This is NOT a new abstraction layer or StoreManager — the orchestrator remains the single coordinator. This is purely consolidating per-store logic into a proper type instead of scattering it across orchestrator methods.

title: MergeStores overwrites WriteTS, breaking time-range queries
description:
When merging stores, copyRecords calls dstCM.Append(rec). The chunk manager's Append always overwrites record.WriteTS with m.cfg.Now(), discarding the original write timestamp. This causes merged records to appear as if they were written at merge time rather than their original ingest time. Time-range queries (which use WriteTS for Start/End bounds) will exclude merged records that fall outside the merge-time window—e.g. a record originally from Jan 1 merged on Jan 15 will have WriteTS=Jan15 and be missed by a query for Jan 1–5.

## Revised approach: move chunks, don't rewrite records

The query engine already handles overlapping time spans across chunks in the same store via heap-based merge-sort (by IngestTS). This means we can simply **move the source store's chunks (and their indexes) into the destination store** instead of reading/rewriting every record.

Benefits:
- WriteTS is preserved (fixes the bug)
- Indexes are preserved (no rebuild needed)
- Much faster (no record-by-record I/O)
- No ordering concerns within chunks

### Same-backend merge (e.g. file→file)
Move/rename chunk directories from source store into destination store. Trivial.

### Cross-backend merge (e.g. memory→file)
Requires rewriting chunks into the destination backend format. Could use a header flag on the destination chunk to mark it as "merging" so the query engine ignores it until the rewrite is complete. Records must be copied preserving all timestamps (WriteTS, IngestTS, SourceTS). Once rewrite finishes, clear the flag and build indexes.
notes: Design: The only correct way to merge is to merge two stores into a third, empty store. Create empty C, sort combined A+B stream by WriteTS, append to C preserving WriteTS, then delete A and B. Merging into an existing destination inherently risks non-monotonic WriteTS or wrong ordering.
close_reason: MergeStores now moves chunk directories for file↔file merges (preserving all timestamps), and uses AppendPreserved for cross-backend merges. Clone/Migrate also preserve WriteTS now.

title: Move long-running store jobs into scheduler with job IDs for progress monitoring
description: Currently ReindexStore, CloneStore, MergeStore, and MigrateStore run synchronously in RPC handlers, blocking until completion. Move these into the shared job scheduler (used for index builds, retention, rotation). Each scheduled job should have a unique ID returned to the requester immediately, allowing progress monitoring (e.g. via a GetJobStatus RPC or similar). The scheduler already has RunOnce and concurrency limits; extend as needed to support job tracking and status queries.

title: Add Jobs tab to Inspector with streaming job updates
description: Add a "Jobs" tab to the Inspector dialog that shows all scheduler jobs (recurring cron jobs and one-time async tasks). Instead of polling, add a WatchJobs server-streaming RPC to the JobService that pushes the full job list whenever state changes (job started, progress update, completed, failed). For cron jobs show name, schedule, last run, and next run. For one-time tasks show name, status, progress (chunks/records), and errors with a progress indicator while running. Replace the existing polling-based useJobs hook with a streaming version.

title: CloneStore should support choosing destination storage type
description: CloneStore currently hardcodes the destination type to match the source (srcCfg.Type). The proto has destination_params but no destination_type field (only MigrateStore has that). Add a destination_type field to CloneStoreRequest so users can clone across storage engines (e.g. memory to file). This would also make the 'clone+delete' workaround viable as an alternative to MergeStores for cross-backend scenarios.

title: Add Ingester/Store should prompt for type before showing config card
description: When adding a new ingester or store, the UI immediately opens a config card with a default type. The user then has to find and change the type dropdown after the fact. Instead, present a type selection dropdown/dialog first, then open the config card pre-populated with the correct type. This avoids the friction of hunting for the type field in an already-open form.

title: Replace Clone with Migrate, restrict Merge
description:
The current store operations (clone, merge, migrate) overlap. Clone serves no real purpose — the query engine searches all stores, so having a copy is pointless. Simplify to two operations: Migrate and Merge.

## Remove CloneStore

Delete the RPC, handler, frontend UI, and hook. No longer needed.

## MigrateStore (three-phase move)

The primary operation for moving a store to a new name, type, and/or location. Orchestrates existing primitives:

1. **Create destination store** with the same filters/policy as the source, enable it — new ingested data starts flowing there immediately.
2. **Disable source store and seal all unsealed chunks** — source is now frozen, no new records flow in (back pressure handles in-flight data).
3. **Merge source into destination, delete source when done** — drains the now-static source into the active destination.

This avoids the race condition of copying while new data arrives. The source becomes a frozen snapshot the moment migration starts.

## Restrict MergeStores

Keep for consolidating stores, but add safety guards:
- Target store must be disabled or have no filters applied, to prevent silent data loss from filter mismatches.
- Auto-seal any unsealed chunks in the source before merging.

Note: the merge restrictions are naturally satisfied during MigrateStore because step 2 disables the source.

title: Convert config IDs from string to uuid.UUID
description: All config entity IDs (StoreConfig.ID, FilterConfig.ID, RotationPolicyConfig.ID, RetentionPolicyConfig.ID) are typed as string. This means the compiler cannot distinguish a store ID from a store name, leading to bugs like passing req.Msg.Destination (a user-typed name) into an ID field. Convert all ID fields to uuid.UUID, propagate through orchestrator registry, config stores (memory, file, SQLite), server handlers, and tests. The proto boundary stays string — parse to uuid.UUID at the server layer.

title: Move data movement logic from server to orchestrator
description:
server/store_operations.go (613 lines) contains business logic that belongs in the orchestrator layer. MigrateStore (127 lines), MergeStores (106 lines), copyRecordsTracked (65 lines), and moveChunksTracked (59 lines) all make decisions about when to seal chunks, how to move them between stores, and when to build indexes. These are orchestration concerns, not RPC handler concerns.

The fix is to add orchestrator methods like MigrateStoreAsync(src, dst, opts) and MergeStoresAsync(src, dst, opts) that encapsulate the multi-phase workflows. The server layer should only parse proto requests and call orchestrator methods.
close_reason: Moved MigrateStore/MergeStores logic to orchestrator with callback pattern

title: Eliminate direct ChunkManager/IndexManager access from server
description:
The server package bypasses orchestrator coordination by reaching directly into internal managers via s.orch.ChunkManager(storeID) and s.orch.IndexManager(storeID) — at least 15 call sites across store_info.go, store_chunks.go, and store_operations.go. This allows the server to call .Seal(), .Append(), .BuildIndexes() etc. without going through orchestrator routing logic, breaking encapsulation.

The fix is to either:
1. Add orchestrator facade methods for the operations the server needs (ReindexChunk, ListChunkMetas, GetChunkDetails, etc.)
2. Or make ChunkManager/IndexManager accessors package-private and expose purpose-specific APIs instead.
close_reason: Implemented: 15 facade methods in orchestrator/store_ops.go, all server files updated

title: Move histogram and context queries from server to query engine
description:
server/query.go contains ~370 lines of index query logic that belongs in the query engine:

- Histogram() (157 lines): performs binary searches on idx.log, reads WriteTS from chunks, buckets results by time. Uses cm.FindStartPosition() directly.
- histogramChunkFast() (46 lines): binary search on ChunkManager.
- histogramChunkSeverity() (79 lines): opens KV indexes, extracts positions, reads timestamps.
- GetContext() (133 lines): seeks to record positions and reads surrounding records.

The server is constructing index.NewKVIndexReader() and doing low-level position lookups — this is query engine work. The fix is to add query.Engine.Histogram(query) and query.Engine.GetContext(ref, before, after) methods, then have the server handlers only do proto conversion.
close_reason: Moved histogram and GetContext logic to query engine

title: Extract sub-components from Orchestrator god object
description:
The Orchestrator type has 52 public methods across 14 files (6569 total lines) and handles too many responsibilities: component registration, configuration management, lifecycle management, scheduling, and statistics tracking.

Candidates for extraction into dedicated types:
- Scheduler (already in scheduler.go, 539 lines, 16 methods) — could become a standalone managed component with its own initialization
- FilterManager — filter compilation, filter set management, and routing logic
- LifecycleManager — Start/Stop/ingestLoop/processMessage
- StatsTracker — ingester statistics collection

The orchestrator would still coordinate these components but delegate the actual work, reducing its method count and making each concern independently testable.
close_reason: Split reconfig.go and store_ops.go into focused files, made FilterSet self-managing, removed 6 deprecated registry methods. Committed and pushed on backend/gastrolog-iwoo.

title: Break up ApplyConfig into focused functions
description:
orchestrator/factory.go ApplyConfig() is 188 lines and blends three distinct concerns:

1. Chunk/Index manager factory invocation (lines 101-120): looks up factory by type, clones params, injects _expect_existing, creates manager
2. Filter compilation (lines 88-98, 131-162): resolves filter ID to expression, compiles filter expressions, manages FilterSet
3. Store/Ingester registration (lines 178-220): calls AddStore for each config, AddIngester for each ingester, handles duplicate detection

Split into ApplyStores(), ApplyIngesters(), and ApplyFilters() so that changes to any one subsystem don't require reading through the entire function.

title: Reduce ConfigServer bidirectional coupling with orchestrator
description:
ConfigServer (45 methods across 8 files) both reads/writes the config store AND coordinates with the orchestrator for hot updates (UpdateFilters, UpdateRotationPolicies, etc.), creating bidirectional coupling: server → config store and server → orchestrator → config store.

The hot-update path means the server is acting as a mediator between config and orchestrator. Consider:
1. An event-based approach where config changes emit events that the orchestrator subscribes to
2. Or moving the hot-update coordination into the orchestrator itself, so the server only writes to the config store and the orchestrator picks up changes

This would make the config flow unidirectional: server → config store → orchestrator.

title: Monitor query scanner filter function growth
description:
query/scanner.go (831 lines) contains 20+ filter application functions (applyTokenIndex, tokenFilter, applyKVIndex, kvFilter, negativePredicatesFilter, dnfFilter, matchesBranch, evalPredicate, etc.). The code is currently well-organized with a clear pattern — each filter type has an index-based apply function and a runtime fallback.

No immediate action needed, but as new filter types are added, this file will grow. If it exceeds ~1000 lines, consider splitting into scanner_index.go (index-based position gathering) and scanner_runtime.go (runtime record filtering).

title: Add ESLint configuration
description: The frontend has no linter configured — 'bun run lint' returns 'Script not found'. Set up ESLint with a TypeScript-aware config (eslint.config.ts with @typescript-eslint), React hooks rules, and import ordering. Add a lint script to package.json.

title: Follow mode stops updating after store migration
description:
When a Follow stream is active and a store is migrated (e.g. memory → file), the stream silently stops producing records. The frontend remains in follow mode but never receives new data.

Root cause: Engine.Follow() captured the store list once at initialization. After migration deletes the old store and creates a new one with a different UUID, the poll loop kept querying the deleted store ID — getting nil back and silently producing nothing.

Fixed by re-evaluating the store list on each poll iteration, initializing positions for newly discovered stores so history isn't replayed.
close_reason: Fixed in branch refactor/gastrolog-2vo4 — Follow() re-evaluates store list each poll iteration

title: Remove REPL (YAGNI)
description: The REPL (internal/repl/) was useful during early development but adds maintenance burden without clear user value — the web UI and API cover all use cases. Remove the REPL package, the -repl flag, and any REPL-specific client interfaces.
close_reason: Removed entire backend/internal/repl/ package (17 files, ~3440 lines), cleaned up dependencies and docs.

title: Replace dialog tab headers with sidebar navigation for Settings and Inspector
description: The HelpDialog's left sidebar for topic selection works well and should be reused for the Settings and Inspector dialogs. Currently both use DialogTabHeader which crams tabs into the title bar. Migrate them to a sidebar layout matching HelpDialog's pattern — scrollable left nav with copper highlight on the active item, content area on the right. This will give more room for future tabs and create a consistent dialog UX across the app.
close_reason: Sidebar navigation implemented for Settings, Inspector, and Help dialogs. DialogTabHeader removed.

title: Add Mermaid diagram rendering to help system
description: The HelpDialog uses react-markdown which doesn't support Mermaid diagrams. Add Mermaid rendering support so help topics can include architecture diagrams, flowcharts, etc. via ```mermaid code blocks.
close_reason: Mermaid rendering added with Observatory theming, dark/light support, and memoized components

title: Rename datadir to home
description: Rename the 'datadir' concept to 'home' throughout the codebase. The global application directory (config database, user credentials, ingester bookmarks) is called 'datadir' but this name is endlessly confusing because it sounds like it should contain log data. The actual log data lives in per-store 'dir' paths set by the user. Rename to 'home' which follows the well-understood CARGO_HOME/GRADLE_HOME pattern. Touches: CLI flag (-datadir → -home), internal/datadir/ package, variable names, CLAUDE.md, justfile, help docs.

title: Show store names instead of UUIDs in policy 'used by' references
description: The rotation and retention policy settings panels show "Used by: <uuid>" when listing which stores reference a policy. These should display the human-readable store name instead (or name + ID if disambiguation is needed). Currently useless for anyone trying to understand which stores are affected.

title: Refine help topics for consistent detail level and readability
description: The help topics vary wildly in depth and density. Some sections dive into implementation minutiae (binary format sizes, exact byte offsets) while others stay high-level. This inconsistency makes the docs hard to read — users hit a wall of technical detail in one topic and then get hand-wavy coverage in the next. Need a pass to normalize the detail level, trim excessive implementation specifics, and improve readability throughout.

title: Key dictionary encoding for attr.log
description:
attr.log currently encodes attributes per-record as [count:u16][keyLen:u16][key bytes][valLen:u16][val bytes]... — every record repeats the full key strings. With ~20K records per chunk sharing the same handful of keys (host, service, level, etc.), this wastes significant space. attr.log is the largest file in a chunk (36% of total with chatterbox data).

Introduce a per-chunk key dictionary:
- New file: attr_dict.log — append-only list of [keyLen:u16][key bytes], key ID = positional index
- Writer maintains map[string]uint16 in memory for the active chunk, appends to attr_dict.log on first occurrence of a key
- attr.log record format changes from [keyLen:u16][key bytes][valLen:u16][val bytes] to [keyID:u16][valLen:u16][val bytes] per attribute
- Reader loads the dictionary file on cursor open, uses it to decode attr records
- No special seal-time processing — dictionary is complete by seal time
- Dictionary file is tiny (hundreds of bytes for typical key sets)

This is fully append-only on both files, preserving the existing write pattern. Estimated savings: 25-40% of attr.log size depending on key/value ratio.

title: Support human-friendly and locale-aware timestamp formats in queries
description:
Query time bounds (start, end, source_start, source_end, ingest_start, ingest_end) currently only accept RFC 3339 format (2024-01-15T08:00:00Z) and Unix timestamps. This is verbose and unfriendly for non-developers.

Add support for:

- Relaxed ISO formats: 2024-01-15, 2024-01-15 08:00, 2024-01-15T08:00 (no seconds), no-Z implies local timezone
- Locale-aware date parsing: Use the browser's regional settings to determine date component order — 1/15/2024 (US) vs 15/1/2024 (EU) vs 2024/1/15 (ISO). Frontend parses to RFC 3339 before sending to backend.
- Natural language: yesterday, today, 3 hours ago, last monday, this morning
- Time-only: 08:00 (implies today)

Parsing should happen on the frontend (which has access to locale and timezone info), normalizing to RFC 3339 before the query hits the backend. The backend remains strict.

title: Toast flood on stale resume token (chunk no longer exists)
description:
When a resume token references a chunk that no longer exists, the frontend enters a retry loop where each failed attempt produces a new error toast: `[invalid_argument] invalid resume token: chunk no longer exists`. This floods the screen with identical notifications.

Two fixes needed:
1. Stop retrying on `invalid_argument` errors — clear the resume token and either restart the query fresh or surface a single error
2. Deduplicate or suppress toasts from auto-retry errors so they don't stack up even if retries do occur

title: Switch CLI argument parsing from flag to Cobra
description: Replace the standard library flag package in backend/cmd/gastrolog/main.go with spf13/cobra for CLI argument parsing. This gives us subcommands, better help output, and a more conventional CLI experience. Current flags (-server, -config-type, -home, -pprof, -bootstrap) become flags on appropriate subcommands (e.g. gastrolog server --bootstrap).

title: Serve frontend from backend with --ui-dir flag
description: The backend should serve the built frontend assets as static files alongside the Connect RPC API. Add a --ui-dir flag to the server subcommand that points to the directory containing the built frontend (e.g. frontend/dist). When set, the server serves static files from that directory on the same listener. This eliminates the need for a separate web server or Vite proxy in production.

title: Embed frontend in binary and expand server CLI flags
description:
Embed the built frontend assets into the gastrolog binary using go:embed. The server serves the embedded UI alongside the Connect RPC API — single binary, no external files.

CLI flags to add to the server subcommand:
- --ui-addr: address for the web UI listener (separate from the API --addr, or same if desired)
- --log-level: minimum log level (debug/info/warn/error), currently hardcoded to info
- --log-format: text (default) or json for production structured logging

Build pipeline: the frontend must be built (bun run build) before go build so the dist output can be embedded.

title: Embed built frontend assets into Go binary
description: Use go:embed to embed the built frontend (frontend/dist) into the gastrolog binary. The server serves the embedded UI alongside the Connect RPC API — single binary deployment, no external files. Frontend must be built (bun run build) before go build.

title: Login page flickers in an infinite render loop

Every mount triggers a refetch, which flips isLoading true (rendering a blank div), then resolves and renders the form, then immediately refetches again. Fix: remove staleTime: 0 so it inherits the 30s default from the QueryClient.

title: GitHub Actions release pipeline (CI + release workflow)
description:
Add GitHub Actions workflows for CI and automated releases. Reference implementation: kluzzebass/reflag.

**CI workflow** (push/PR to main):
- Build and test (go build ./..., go test ./...)

**Release workflow** (triggered by v* tag push):
- Build frontend (bun install + bun run build)
- Brotli-compress and embed frontend assets into Go binary
- Build cross-platform binaries (linux amd64/arm64, darwin amd64/arm64) with version injection via ldflags
- Generate SHA256 checksums
- Create GitHub Release with binaries + checksums
- Build and push Docker image
- Generate Homebrew formula and push to kluzzebass/homebrew-tap

No Windows target. No glibc/musl split (pure Go, no CGO).

title: Multi-arch Docker builds in release workflow
description: The release workflow currently builds a single linux/amd64 Docker image. Add multi-arch support (linux/amd64 + linux/arm64) using docker/build-push-action with QEMU so the image works natively on both x86 and ARM hosts (including Apple Silicon via Docker Desktop).

title: Add About section to help system
description: Add an About topic to the help dialog showing copyright, license (MIT), repo link, third-party asset attribution (stomach icon, CC BY 3.0), and a table of external dependencies requiring attribution (backend Go deps + frontend npm deps).

title: Docker Compose and Dockerfile improvements
description: Improvements to compose.yml and Dockerfile for production use: expose all service ports (HTTP, HTTPS, Syslog UDP/TCP, HTTP/Loki, RELP), set default --home /config in Dockerfile CMD, and add persistent volumes for config and store data.

title: Squash SQLite migrations into a single init migration
description: There are currently 12 incremental SQLite migrations (001_init through 012_surrogate_keys). Since the project is not yet in production, squash them all into a single 001_init.sql that creates the final schema directly. This gives new installs a clean starting point and removes accumulated ALTER TABLE / column addition steps that only existed for dev iteration. Delete existing dev databases after squashing.

title: Add Skip button to setup wizard
description: The setup wizard currently forces users through all 5 steps with no way to skip. Add a Skip button that navigates directly to the search view with a completely blank configuration (no stores, no ingesters, no policies). Users can then configure everything manually through Settings.

title: Show password policy rules inline during password entry
description: The change password dialog should display password policy requirements (minimum length, etc.) as the user types, with real-time feedback showing which rules are satisfied and which are not. Rules should be visible before the user submits, not as an error after the fact.

title: Add "Recipes" help section with client-side configuration guides for ingesters
description:
The ingester help pages explain GastroLog's configuration parameters but don't cover how to configure the sending side. Users need step-by-step recipes for common setups like:

- Docker daemon TCP with mTLS (generate CA, server cert, client cert, configure dockerd, configure GastroLog)
- rsyslog → Syslog/RELP (rsyslog.conf snippets for UDP, TCP, RELP)
- Promtail/Grafana Agent → HTTP ingester
- systemd journal → Syslog or RELP ingester (via rsyslog forwarding)

Add a top-level "Recipes" help topic with individual recipe pages, cross-referenced from the relevant ingester topics.

title: Unify Docker ingester filters with querylang filter engine
description:
The Docker ingester currently uses three separate, simple filter params (label_filter, name_filter, image_filter) with no boolean logic between them — they're just ANDed. The querylang filter engine already supports full boolean expressions (AND, OR, NOT, globs, regex) over map[string]string, which is exactly what Docker container metadata is.

Replace the three standalone filter params with a single `filter` param that accepts a querylang expression. Container metadata would be flattened into attributes like:

- `image` — image name/tag
- `name` — container name
- `label.<key>` — Docker labels with prefix

Example: `image~"nginx*" AND (label.env="prod" OR label.env="staging")`

Steps:
1. Export the evaluation functions from orchestrator (matchesAttrs, evalAttrPredicate) — or move them to querylang where they arguably belong
2. In the Docker ingester, flatten container metadata into a map[string]string
3. Replace containerFilter struct with a compiled querylang DNF filter
4. Deprecate label_filter, name_filter, image_filter in favor of the unified `filter` param
5. Update the ingester-docker help page and the Docker mTLS recipe (recipe-docker-mtls) to document the new filter syntax

title: Chatterbox help doc missing attributes and format descriptions
description:
The ingester-chatterbox.md help page only lists params and format names. It's missing:

- Attributes table showing what each format emits (service, host, env, vhost, facility, format, language, command vary by format)
- Descriptions of what each format generates (plain text, KV pairs, JSON, Apache combined log, RFC 3164 syslog, malformed data, multi-line stack traces)
- SourceTS behavior (json/access/syslog/multirecord set it; plain/kv/weird don't)

title: Route help navigation via URL search param for browser back/forward
description:
Help navigation is pure React state — no URL representation. Browser back/forward buttons don't work with help topics, and help state is lost on page refresh.

Put help topics in a URL search param (e.g. `?help=ingester-docker`) instead of React state. This gives:

- Browser back button closes help / goes to previous topic
- Forward button re-opens it
- Deep-linking to help topics (`/follow?q=error&help=query-language`)
- Underlying page (search/follow) stays mounted — streaming connections uninterrupted

Implementation: add `help?: string` to the TanStack Router search schema, replace `showHelpDialog`/`helpTopic` state with router search params. HelpDialog renders when `help` param is present, navigating between topics uses `router.navigate({ search: { help: topicId } })`.

title: Route settings and inspector dialogs via URL search params
description:
Follow-up to gastrolog-ochp. Settings and inspector dialogs should use URL search params like help does, so browser back/forward works and deep-linking is possible.

Add `?settings=<tab>` and `?inspector=<tab>` search params. Opening a dialog pushes a history entry, switching tabs updates the URL, closing removes the param. The underlying page stays mounted — follow mode streams uninterrupted.

title: Make HTTPS port configurable in service settings
description: The HTTPS listener port is currently derived as HTTP port + 1 (e.g. :4565 when HTTP is :4564). This should be configurable from the service settings UI instead of being hardcoded arithmetic.

title: Move user preferences into a JSON column on the users table
description:
User preferences (theme, saved queries) are currently stored as synthetic keys in the settings table (user:<id>:prefs, user:<id>:saved_queries). This pollutes the settings table with per-user data and makes it impossible to clean up orphaned prefs when a user is deleted.

Add a preferences TEXT JSON column to the users table in 001_init.sql. Update config_user.go to read/write from the users row instead of the settings table. Cascade-deletes user data for free.

No need to migrate existing data — the system is not yet released.

title: Histogram missing severity colors in search mode
description: The filtered path in the histogram engine (used whenever a search expression is present) only increments total counts per bucket but never populates levelCounts. The unfiltered path correctly calls histogramChunkSeverity for index-based severity counting, but the filtered path scans records without checking their level or severity_name attributes. Result: severity-colored bars only appear in follow mode (client-side bucketing) and in unfiltered searches.

title: Inline icon support in help markdown
description: Help files reference UI icons by name (e.g. 'the bookmark icon') instead of showing the actual icons. Add a custom syntax like :icon-bookmark: that the markdown renderer replaces with inline SVGs matching the real UI icons.
close_reason: Implemented inline icon support, settings: links, help button SVG, mermaid rerender fix, and various help content improvements

title: Set up React Compiler and remove redundant memoization
description: 1. Enable the React Compiler (babel-plugin-react-compiler) in vite.config.ts via @vitejs/plugin-react. 2. Audit all useMemo, useCallback, React.memo usage across the frontend and remove any that the compiler makes redundant. The compiler auto-memoizes components and hooks, so most manual memoization can be deleted. Notable candidates: HelpDialog mdComponents useMemo with ref-based callback stabilization, and any other manually memoized values/callbacks.

title: Tighten up frontend to modern React standards
description: Thorough code review and modernization of the frontend codebase. Bring everything up to current React 19 best practices, clean up patterns that have accumulated organically, and ensure consistency across the codebase.

title: Fix ESLint/TypeScript warnings across the frontend
description:
There are a large number of SonarQube/TypeScript warnings across the frontend codebase. Audit and fix them all for a clean editor experience.

Warning categories found:

- **S6759** — Mark component props as read-only (wrap prop types with Readonly<>)
- **S3358** — Nested ternary operations (common in dark/light theme c() pattern)
- **S1082/S6847/S6848** — Accessibility: click handlers on non-interactive elements, missing keyboard listeners, non-native interactive elements
- **S6479** — Array index used as React key
- **S3776** — Cognitive complexity exceeds threshold (components too complex, need splitting)
- **S2004** — Functions nested more than 4 levels deep
- **S1874** — Deprecated APIs (e.g. React.FormEvent)
- **S7764** — Use globalThis instead of window
- **S6819** — Use native <dialog> element instead of role="dialog"

title: Remove useless render-time clock from ResultsToolbar
description: The ResultsToolbar displays new Date().toLocaleTimeString() next to the export button. This just shows the wall clock time at last render — it's not tied to any record or search result and serves no purpose. Remove it.

title: Storage stat should use actual disk bytes, not logical bytes
description: The GetStats RPC sums meta.Bytes (logical/uncompressed size) for the storage figure, but meta.DiskBytes (actual on-disk size including compression) is available for sealed chunks. This overstates storage usage when compression is enabled. Use DiskBytes when available, falling back to Bytes for active chunks where DiskBytes isn't yet computed. Also avoids double-counting index sizes since DiskBytes already includes all files in the chunk directory.

title: Investigate Windows support
description:
The codebase has a small number of Unix-specific syscalls that prevent building on Windows. The blockers are contained:

- syscall.Mmap/Munmap in record_reader.go and token/indexer.go (sealed chunk reads, index writes)
- syscall.Flock in manager.go (directory locking)
- syscall.EXDEV in move.go (cross-device rename detection)
- syscall.Stat_t in tail/ingester.go (inode-based file identity)

Options for mmap: use golang.org/x/exp/mmap, switch to ReadAt/WriteAt, or use build tags with platform-specific implementations. The flock and inode usages need minor platform abstractions.

title: Clickable example values in settings form inputs
description: Settings forms (ingesters, stores, policies) show example values in description text and placeholders. These are often sensible defaults the user would want to use verbatim, but currently must be typed manually. Add clickable chips below inputs that fill the value on click. Only show when the input is empty.

title: Search loads infinite rows when expression is empty
description: When the search field contains only directives (last=15m reverse=true) and no actual search expression, the search still fires and returns all records. Infinite scroll then keeps loading more pages endlessly. Need a guard to skip search when the expression (stripped of directives) is empty.

title: Bare token search fails for IP addresses and other dotted/numeric values
description:
Searching for bare tokens like IP addresses (e.g. 72.11.138.26) returns no results even when records containing them are visible.

Root cause: tokenization mismatch between query parser and record indexer. The query parser treats dotted values as a single bareword, but the record tokenizer splits on dots and discards pure-numeric segments. The runtime filter (matchesSingleToken) then looks for the full IP as a single token in the record's token list, which can never match.

When a bare token is not indexable (contains characters outside the token alphabet), the search should fall back to a raw content scan of chunks that match the rest of the expression, rather than silently returning no results.

Add a migration policy that automatically moves sealed chunks from one store to another based on age (and potentially size). This enables tiered storage similar to Splunk's hot/warm/cold model:

- Active chunk = hot (accepting writes)
- Sealed chunk in fast store = warm (recent, fast queries)  
- Auto-migrated to cheaper/slower store = cold (older, still searchable)
- Retention policy deletes = expired

A migration policy would attach to a source store and specify a destination store plus conditions (e.g., maxAge: 168h moves chunks older than 7 days). The mechanism is similar to the existing manual Migrate operation in StoresSettings but triggered automatically by the scheduler.

Design considerations:
- New policy type (migration policy) alongside rotation and retention
- Backend-agnostic: works between any store types (file→file, file→S3, memory→file, etc.)
- May require new storage backends (S3, GCS) to be useful for cold tier
- Multiple tiers possible: chain migration policies (fast-file → slow-file → S3)
- Chunks remain searchable at every tier
