title: fix: histogram double animation on search
description: The volume histogram bar chart plays its entrance animation twice in rapid succession when a search is performed. Root cause: echarts-for-react uses fast-deep-equal to compare the option prop, and the tooltipFormatter function reference is new every render, causing unnecessary setOption calls with notMerge that replay the entrance animation. Fix: stabilize the formatter via ref indirection so fast-deep-equal sees a stable reference.

title: feat: Docker Compose integration test environment for ingesters
description:
Create a unified docker-compose.yml that brings up real-world services for integration-testing all ingesters end-to-end:

- Kafka broker (KRaft) for the kafka ingester
- rsyslog forwarding to gastrolog's syslog and RELP ingesters
- Fluent Bit / Fluentd forwarding via Fluent Forward protocol
- OpenTelemetry Collector sending logs via OTLP
- Docker container log ingestion (gastrolog reads from Docker API)
- HTTP log generator pushing logs to the HTTP ingester

The compose file should also bring up a gastrolog instance configured with all ingesters enabled, plus small log-generator sidecars that produce synthetic traffic so the environment is immediately useful for manual testing and future automated integration tests.

Goal: a single docker compose up that validates all ingesters work against the real services they're designed to handle.

comments.author: kluzz@radical.org
comments.text: No custom log generators — rely on the real services' own logging output (Kafka broker logs, rsyslog internal messages, OTel collector telemetry, etc.) to avoid implementation biases. The compose environment should exercise the ingesters with genuine, unscripted log traffic.

comments.author: kluzz@radical.org
comments.text: For OTLP: use an OTel Collector configured to report its own internal telemetry (self-monitoring). That gives us real OTLP log traffic without needing a separate app. Kafka covers itself naturally via broker logs.

comments.author: kluzz@radical.org
comments.text: Design principle: minimal container count, real log data only. Each container must be a genuine service that produces real logs as a byproduct of its normal operation — no custom scripts or synthetic generators. Prefer services that double up (e.g., Kafka broker logs ingested via both the kafka ingester and syslog if rsyslog is collecting from it).

title: feat: reintroduce JSON config as bootstrap-only feature
description: Reintroduce JSON config file support, but only as a bootstrap mechanism — not as a living config store. The JSON file would seed the SQLite config store on first run (or when --bootstrap is passed), providing a declarative way to define the initial setup for deployment scenarios. Once bootstrapped, the SQLite store is the sole source of truth and the JSON file is not watched or re-read.

title: feat: expand compression support on ingesters
description:
Current state: gzip decompression is supported on OTLP HTTP, HTTP/Loki, and Fluent Forward (CompressedPackedForward). Gaps:

- **OTLP gRPC**: no compression registered on the gRPC server — needs grpc encoding registration for gzip and zstd so clients can send compressed payloads
- **OTLP HTTP**: only gzip — the OTLP spec also defines zstd as a supported Content-Encoding
- **HTTP/Loki**: only gzip — add zstd support
- **Kafka**: compression (snappy, lz4, zstd, gzip) is handled at the protocol layer by franz-go — verify it works transparently
- **Syslog/RELP**: compression is not standard for these protocols, no action needed

Goal: accept compressed payloads from real-world clients (OTel Collector, Promtail/Alloy, Fluent Bit) without requiring them to disable compression.

title: Investigate S3 and Azure Blob Storage for slow, cheap chunk storage
description: Look into how S3 and Azure Blob Storage can be used as a cold/archive tier for chunk storage. The idea is to offer a slow but cheap storage backend for chunks that are rarely queried, complementing the existing local disk stores. Key questions: what SDK/libraries to use, how to handle reads (streaming vs download), how this fits into the existing store abstraction, cost implications, and whether we need a local cache layer in front of remote storage.

title: SQLite database lookup table
description: Add support for looking up data in SQLite databases as a lookup table source for the pipeline `lookup` operator. This would allow users to enrich log records with data from arbitrary SQLite databases, e.g. `| lookup mydb user_id` where `mydb` is a configured SQLite file. Key considerations: read-only access, connection pooling or single-conn, mapping between lookup key and result columns, how to configure the table/query, and whether to support custom SQL or just simple key-value lookups.

title: HTTP API lookup table
description: Add support for enriching log records via HTTP API calls. Syntax: `| lookup http://internal-api/users user_id`. Uses stdlib `net/http`, no external drivers needed. The lookup operator would make a GET request with the key value and map the JSON response fields into record attributes. Key considerations: LRU cache with TTL to avoid hammering endpoints on repeated keys, timeout configuration, authentication headers, error handling (skip vs fail), and rate limiting.

title: JSON file lookup table
description: Add support for looking up data in JSON files as a lookup table source. Similar to the CSV table (gastrolog-4i3q) but for structured/nested data. Load a JSON file keyed by a field, flatten the matched object into record attributes. Zero external dependencies. Key considerations: file format (object keyed by lookup value vs array with key field), nested object flattening strategy, hot-reload on file change, and memory footprint for large files.

title: CIDR/subnet lookup table
description: Add a lookup table that matches IP addresses against CIDR ranges to produce network zone, owner, environment, or other labels. Uses pure stdlib `net/netip`, no external dependencies. Configuration: a file mapping CIDR ranges to attributes (e.g. `10.0.0.0/8 -> zone=internal, env=prod`). Useful for network log analysis without needing GeoIP. Key considerations: efficient prefix matching (radix tree or sorted search), IPv4/IPv6 support, file format (CSV, JSON, or custom), and hot-reload.

title: Self-lookup: enrich from GastroLog query results
description: Add a lookup table that enriches records using GastroLog's own query results. E.g., reference a saved aggregation (average response time per service from the last hour) and join it onto current records. No external drivers needed, but architecturally complex — needs to define how subqueries are specified (inline vs saved/named), caching/staleness semantics, and how to avoid circular dependencies. This is the most powerful but also most complex lookup type.

title: GraphQL API lookup table
description: Add support for enriching log records via GraphQL API calls using the `github.com/kluzzebass/gqlt` client library. The lookup operator would execute a GraphQL query with the key value as a variable and map the response fields into record attributes. Key considerations: query template configuration, variable mapping, response field flattening, LRU cache with TTL, timeout and authentication, error handling (skip vs fail), and rate limiting.

title: Backend-driven field discovery and query validation
description:
The frontend currently approximates field extraction with a `key=value` regex (`extractKVPairs`), but the backend runs richer extractors (KV, logfmt, access log, JSON) via `tokenizer.CombinedExtract`. This means fields like `remote_host`, `method`, `path` from access log lines never appear in autocomplete or the sidebar.

More broadly, the frontend duplicates query validation logic (tokenizer, keyword sets, structural checks) that the backend's parser is the source of truth for. These should converge.

## Pipeline-aware field context

Each pipeline operator can change the available field set. An `eval` adds fields, `rename` replaces them, `fields -` drops them, `lookup` adds suffixed fields, and `stats` replaces the entire schema with aggregation columns. Autocomplete suggestions need to reflect the field set *at the cursor position in the pipeline* — not just the raw record fields. This means the backend needs to simulate the pipeline up to the cursor and report what fields would exist at that point.

## Proposed RPCs

1. **`GetFields`** — Given a query expression + time range + pipeline position, sample matching records, simulate operators up to the cursor, and return the resulting field set. Replaces the frontend's `aggregateFields` + `extractKVPairs`.

2. **`ValidateQuery`** — Given a partial or complete expression + cursor position, return parse errors and contextual suggestions. Replaces the frontend's tokenizer-based validation and could power autocomplete directly.

title.new: Separate certificate storage from TLS server settings in config store

description.new:
PutTLSConfig and GetTLSConfig on the Store interface conflate two unrelated concerns: certificate data (PEM content, file paths) stored in the tls_certificates table, and TLS server settings (enabled, redirect, default_cert) stored in the settings table as part of server config JSON. This coupling causes a non-atomicity issue — PutTLSConfig writes server settings first, then certs in a separate transaction — and is redundant with PutServerConfig which already manages TLS server settings through its own read-modify-write path.

Replace GetTLSConfig/PutTLSConfig with dedicated certificate CRUD methods on the Store interface (e.g. ListCertificates, GetCertificate, PutCertificate, DeleteCertificate). TLS server settings stay exclusively in server config. The API layer's PutCertificate calls both independently: save the cert, then update server config if set_as_default is set.

description.new:
## Problem

When a file store's data directory is missing (deleted, `/tmp` cleanup, disk failure), the chunk manager silently recreates it via `os.MkdirAll` and starts with zero chunks. The server comes up normally with no warning, no error, and no indication that an entire store's worth of log data has been lost.

This is dangerous because:
- An admin would have no way to detect the data loss without manually checking record counts
- `/tmp`-based stores are especially vulnerable to OS cleanup
- Accidental `rm -rf` or disk issues become invisible

## Expected Behavior

On startup, if a file store's directory is missing or empty (no chunk subdirectories) but the store has been previously configured (i.e., it's not a brand-new store being created for the first time), gastrolog should:

1. Log a prominent warning (e.g., `WARN store "foo" data directory was missing or empty, recreated with 0 chunks`)
2. Optionally refuse to start (configurable) if data loss is detected

## Location

- `backend/internal/chunk/file/manager.go` — `NewManager` calls `os.MkdirAll` unconditionally at line ~139
- `backend/internal/orchestrator/factory.go` — `ApplyConfig` creates chunk managers during startup

## Possible Approaches

- Before `MkdirAll`, check if the directory already exists. If it doesn't, set a flag. After `loadExisting()`, if the flag is set and zero chunks were found, log a warning.
- Alternatively, track "expected chunk count" in the config store and compare on startup.

description.new:
After deleting the data directory and restarting, the frontend still holds an old JWT token in localStorage (signed with the now-gone secret). API calls fail with Unauthenticated but the user is never redirected to login — they just see empty data.

Root causes:

1. The Connect RPC transport has no global error interceptor for 401/Unauthenticated responses. Only search and follow errors are caught in App.tsx; all other hooks (config, stores, ingesters) silently fail.

2. useFollow treats 401 as a transient error and enters a reconnect loop instead of redirecting to login.

3. The router's beforeLoad guard only checks that a token exists in localStorage, not that it's valid.

Fix: add a global error interceptor at the transport layer (in client.ts) that catches Code.Unauthenticated, clears the token, and redirects to /login. Remove the per-hook 401 handling in App.tsx once the global interceptor is in place.

title.new: Consolidate orchestrator store registries into a Store struct

description.new:
The orchestrator currently maintains three parallel maps (chunks, indexes, queries) keyed by store ID, with the invariant that every store ID must exist in all three. This is maintained by careful code in reconfig.go and factory.go but isn't structurally enforced.

Introduce a lightweight Store value type:

```go
type Store struct {
    ID      string
    Chunks  chunk.ChunkManager
    Indexes index.IndexManager
    Query   *query.Engine
    Enabled bool
}
```

Replace the three parallel maps with a single `map[string]*Store`. This makes the triplet invariant structural, simplifies the registry accessors, and gives servers (StoreServer, QueryServer) a cleaner interface to work with.

NOT a new abstraction layer or StoreManager — the orchestrator remains the single coordinator. This is purely an internal data structure improvement.

## What moves into Store

Anything that operates on a single store's triplet:

- **Append + seal detection + index triggering** — currently spread across ingest.go, becomes `store.Append(rec)` with seal-detect-then-index as the Store's responsibility
- **Factory wiring** — creating the CM/IM/QE triplet from a StoreConfig becomes a Store constructor
- **Enable/disable** toggling
- **Per-store shutdown** — close CM, wait for index builds

## What stays in the orchestrator

Anything that's cross-store coordination:

- The ingest channel and loop
- Filter routing (`FilterSet.Match` → which stores get a message)
- Ingester lifecycle
- The store registry itself (add/remove/rename/list)

## Non-goals

This is NOT a new abstraction layer or StoreManager — the orchestrator remains the single coordinator. This is purely consolidating per-store logic into a proper type instead of scattering it across orchestrator methods.

description.new: When merging stores, copyRecords calls dstCM.Append(rec). The chunk manager's Append always overwrites record.WriteTS with m.cfg.Now(), discarding the original write timestamp. This causes merged records to appear as if they were written at merge time rather than their original ingest time. Time-range queries (which use WriteTS for Start/End bounds) will exclude merged records that fall outside the merge-time window—e.g. a record originally from Jan 1 merged on Jan 15 will have WriteTS=Jan15 and be missed by a query for Jan 1–5. Fix requires either: (a) Append variant that preserves WriteTS when caller can guarantee monotonic order, or (b) sort merged records by WriteTS before appending and use such a variant. Non-empty destination merge may need special handling to preserve monotonicity.

Time-range queries (which use WriteTS for Start/End bounds) will exclude merged records that fall outside the merge-time window—e.g. a record originally from Jan 1 merged on Jan 15 will have WriteTS=Jan15 and be missed by a query for Jan 1–5. Fix requires either: (a) Append variant that preserves WriteTS when caller can guarantee monotonic order, or (b) sort merged records by WriteTS before appending and use such a variant. Non-empty destination merge may need special handling to preserve monotonicity.
description.new:
When merging stores, copyRecords calls dstCM.Append(rec). The chunk manager's Append always overwrites record.WriteTS with m.cfg.Now(), discarding the original write timestamp. This causes merged records to appear as if they were written at merge time rather than their original ingest time. Time-range queries (which use WriteTS for Start/End bounds) will exclude merged records that fall outside the merge-time window—e.g. a record originally from Jan 1 merged on Jan 15 will have WriteTS=Jan15 and be missed by a query for Jan 1–5.

## Revised approach: move chunks, don't rewrite records

The query engine already handles overlapping time spans across chunks in the same store via heap-based merge-sort (by IngestTS). This means we can simply **move the source store's chunks (and their indexes) into the destination store** instead of reading/rewriting every record.

Benefits:
- WriteTS is preserved (fixes the bug)
- Indexes are preserved (no rebuild needed)
- Much faster (no record-by-record I/O)
- No ordering concerns within chunks

### Same-backend merge (e.g. file→file)
Move/rename chunk directories from source store into destination store. Trivial.

### Cross-backend merge (e.g. memory→file)
Requires rewriting chunks into the destination backend format. Could use a header flag on the destination chunk to mark it as "merging" so the query engine ignores it until the rewrite is complete. Records must be copied preserving all timestamps (WriteTS, IngestTS, SourceTS). Once rewrite finishes, clear the flag and build indexes.

description.new:
The current store operations (clone, merge, migrate) overlap. Clone serves no real purpose — the query engine searches all stores, so having a copy is pointless. Simplify to two operations: Migrate and Merge.

## Remove CloneStore

Delete the RPC, handler, frontend UI, and hook. No longer needed.

## MigrateStore (three-phase move)

The primary operation for moving a store to a new name, type, and/or location. Orchestrates existing primitives:

1. **Create destination store** with the same filters/policy as the source, enable it — new ingested data starts flowing there immediately.
2. **Disable source store and seal all unsealed chunks** — source is now frozen, no new records flow in (back pressure handles in-flight data).
3. **Merge source into destination, delete source when done** — drains the now-static source into the active destination.

This avoids the race condition of copying while new data arrives. The source becomes a frozen snapshot the moment migration starts.

## Restrict MergeStores

Keep for consolidating stores, but add safety guards:
- Target store must be disabled or have no filters applied, to prevent silent data loss from filter mismatches.
- Auto-seal any unsealed chunks in the source before merging.

Note: the merge restrictions are naturally satisfied during MigrateStore because step 2 disables the source.

description.new:
server/store_operations.go (613 lines) contains business logic that belongs in the orchestrator layer. MigrateStore (127 lines), MergeStores (106 lines), copyRecordsTracked (65 lines), and moveChunksTracked (59 lines) all make decisions about when to seal chunks, how to move them between stores, and when to build indexes. These are orchestration concerns, not RPC handler concerns.

The fix is to add orchestrator methods like MigrateStoreAsync(src, dst, opts) and MergeStoresAsync(src, dst, opts) that encapsulate the multi-phase workflows. The server layer should only parse proto requests and call orchestrator methods.

title.new: Eliminate direct ChunkManager/IndexManager access from server

description.new:
The server package bypasses orchestrator coordination by reaching directly into internal managers via s.orch.ChunkManager(storeID) and s.orch.IndexManager(storeID) — at least 15 call sites across store_info.go, store_chunks.go, and store_operations.go. This allows the server to call .Seal(), .Append(), .BuildIndexes() etc. without going through orchestrator routing logic, breaking encapsulation.

The fix is to either:
1. Add orchestrator facade methods for the operations the server needs (ReindexChunk, ListChunkMetas, GetChunkDetails, etc.)
2. Or make ChunkManager/IndexManager accessors package-private and expose purpose-specific APIs instead.

title.new: Move histogram and context queries from server to query engine

description.new:
server/query.go contains ~370 lines of index query logic that belongs in the query engine:

- Histogram() (157 lines): performs binary searches on idx.log, reads WriteTS from chunks, buckets results by time. Uses cm.FindStartPosition() directly.
- histogramChunkFast() (46 lines): binary search on ChunkManager.
- histogramChunkSeverity() (79 lines): opens KV indexes, extracts positions, reads timestamps.
- GetContext() (133 lines): seeks to record positions and reads surrounding records.

The server is constructing index.NewKVIndexReader() and doing low-level position lookups — this is query engine work. The fix is to add query.Engine.Histogram(query) and query.Engine.GetContext(ref, before, after) methods, then have the server handlers only do proto conversion.

description.new:
When a Follow stream is active and a store is migrated (e.g. memory → file), the stream silently stops producing records. The frontend remains in follow mode but never receives new data.

Root cause: Engine.Follow() captured the store list once at initialization. After migration deletes the old store and creates a new one with a different UUID, the poll loop kept querying the deleted store ID — getting nil back and silently producing nothing.

Fixed by re-evaluating the store list on each poll iteration, initializing positions for newly discovered stores so history isn't replayed.

description.new:
attr.log currently encodes attributes per-record as [count:u16][keyLen:u16][key bytes][valLen:u16][val bytes]... — every record repeats the full key strings. With ~20K records per chunk sharing the same handful of keys (host, service, level, etc.), this wastes significant space. attr.log is the largest file in a chunk (36% of total with chatterbox data).

Introduce a per-chunk key dictionary:
- New file: attr_dict.log — append-only list of [keyLen:u16][key bytes], key ID = positional index
- Writer maintains map[string]uint16 in memory for the active chunk, appends to attr_dict.log on first occurrence of a key
- attr.log record format changes from [keyLen:u16][key bytes][valLen:u16][val bytes] to [keyID:u16][valLen:u16][val bytes] per attribute
- Reader loads the dictionary file on cursor open, uses it to decode attr records
- No special seal-time processing — dictionary is complete by seal time
- Dictionary file is tiny (hundreds of bytes for typical key sets)

This is fully append-only on both files, preserving the existing write pattern. Estimated savings: 25-40% of attr.log size depending on key/value ratio.

title.new: Support human-friendly and locale-aware timestamp formats in queries

description.new:
Query time bounds (start, end, source_start, source_end, ingest_start, ingest_end) currently only accept RFC 3339 format (2024-01-15T08:00:00Z) and Unix timestamps. This is verbose and unfriendly for non-developers.

Add support for:

- Relaxed ISO formats: 2024-01-15, 2024-01-15 08:00, 2024-01-15T08:00 (no seconds), no-Z implies local timezone
- Locale-aware date parsing: Use the browser's regional settings to determine date component order — 1/15/2024 (US) vs 15/1/2024 (EU) vs 2024/1/15 (ISO). Frontend parses to RFC 3339 before sending to backend.
- Natural language: yesterday, today, 3 hours ago, last monday, this morning
- Time-only: 08:00 (implies today)

Parsing should happen on the frontend (which has access to locale and timezone info), normalizing to RFC 3339 before the query hits the backend. The backend remains strict.

description.new:
The Docker ingester currently uses three separate, simple filter params (label_filter, name_filter, image_filter) with no boolean logic between them — they're just ANDed. The querylang filter engine already supports full boolean expressions (AND, OR, NOT, globs, regex) over map[string]string, which is exactly what Docker container metadata is.

Replace the three standalone filter params with a single `filter` param that accepts a querylang expression. Container metadata would be flattened into attributes like:

- `image` — image name/tag
- `name` — container name
- `label.<key>` — Docker labels with prefix

Example: `image~"nginx*" AND (label.env="prod" OR label.env="staging")`

Steps:
1. Export the evaluation functions from orchestrator (matchesAttrs, evalAttrPredicate) — or move them to querylang where they arguably belong
2. In the Docker ingester, flatten container metadata into a map[string]string
3. Replace containerFilter struct with a compiled querylang DNF filter
4. Deprecate label_filter, name_filter, image_filter in favor of the unified `filter` param
5. Update the ingester-docker help page and the Docker mTLS recipe (recipe-docker-mtls) to document the new filter syntax

description.new:
Searching for bare tokens like IP addresses (e.g. 72.11.138.26) returns no results even when records containing them are visible.

Root cause: tokenization mismatch between query parser and record indexer. The query parser treats dotted values as a single bareword, but the record tokenizer splits on dots and discards pure-numeric segments. The runtime filter (matchesSingleToken) then looks for the full IP as a single token in the record's token list, which can never match.

When a bare token is not indexable (contains characters outside the token alphabet), the search should fall back to a raw content scan of chunks that match the rest of the expression, rather than silently returning no results.

description.new:
Add a migration policy that automatically moves sealed chunks from one store to another based on age (and potentially size). This enables tiered storage similar to Splunk's hot/warm/cold model:

- Active chunk = hot (accepting writes)
- Sealed chunk in fast store = warm (recent, fast queries)  
- Auto-migrated to cheaper/slower store = cold (older, still searchable)
- Retention policy deletes = expired

A migration policy would attach to a source store and specify a destination store plus conditions (e.g., maxAge: 168h moves chunks older than 7 days). The mechanism is similar to the existing manual Migrate operation in StoresSettings but triggered automatically by the scheduler.

Design considerations:
- New policy type (migration policy) alongside rotation and retention
- Backend-agnostic: works between any store types (file→file, file→S3, memory→file, etc.)
- May require new storage backends (S3, GCS) to be useful for cold tier
- Multiple tiers possible: chain migration policies (fast-file → slow-file → S3)
- Chunks remain searchable at every tier

description.new:
Retention policies define conditions (maxAge, maxBytes, maxChunks). Currently a store references a single retention policy and the action is always delete. This change:

1. Supports multiple retention bindings per store (array instead of single reference).
2. Each binding pairs a retention policy with an action (expire or migrate).

Store config model:

  retention: [
    { policy: "7-day", action: "migrate", destination: "logs-archive" },
    { policy: "max-100GB", action: "expire" }
  ]

Each binding is evaluated independently. A chunk matches whichever policy triggers first — e.g. size-based expiry as a safety valve alongside age-based migration.

Default behavior (single policy, action=expire) is preserved for backward compatibility. The retention policies themselves are unchanged and remain reusable. Rotation policies are unaffected.

The existing manual Migrate operation provides the underlying mechanism for the migrate action.

description.new:
GastroLog's query language currently handles the filter/select phase well (boolean search, key=value, regex, time ranges, index-accelerated scans). But the open aggregation issues (count, time buckets, group-by) are individual features that belong to a larger architectural question: does GastroLog get a pipe-based transformation pipeline?

Every major log system (Splunk SPL, Kusto KQL, Grafana LogQL, Elasticsearch ES|QL, ClickHouse) has converged on separating two phases:

1. **Filter phase** — boolean search against indexes (what we have today)
2. **Transform phase** — a pipeline of operators that reshape the filtered result set

The industry consensus is that pipe-based syntax is the ergonomic winner for interactive analytics. The core operator vocabulary is small:

- `stats`/`summarize` — aggregation with group-by (count, avg, sum, min, max, percentiles, dcount)
- `bin`/`bucket` — time bucketing with gap-filling and alignment
- `eval`/`extend` — computed fields from expressions
- `where` (post-aggregation) — filter on computed values
- `sort` + `limit`/`top` — ordering and truncation
- `parse`/`extract` — query-time field extraction (we already have KV extractors at index time)

Example of what this might look like:

```
service="api" status>=500 last=1h | stats count, avg(duration), p95(duration) by bin(5m), service | where count > 10 | sort -count
```

Design questions:

- What operators do we need for v1? Minimal viable set vs aspirational.
- How does the pipe boundary interact with the existing scanner pipeline? The filter phase produces records; the transform phase produces tables/time-series. This is a fundamental type change.
- Result types: search returns records (infinite scroll), pipeline returns tables or time-series (finite, structured). How does the frontend handle both? (see gastrolog-wl16)
- Approximate algorithms: HyperLogLog for distinct counts, t-digest for percentiles — needed at scale.
- Do we want conditional aggregation (Kusto's `countif`, ClickHouse's `-If` combinator)?
- Does `eventstats` (add aggregate back to events without collapsing) matter for us?
- Query-time field extraction: we have index-time KV extraction already. Do we need `parse`/`rex` style operators for ad-hoc extraction?

This issue is the architectural design. The existing child issues (gastrolog-316n, gastrolog-5991, gastrolog-5oh4) become implementation tasks within whatever pipeline design we choose.

description.new:
The query language currently only supports equality matching for key-value filters (key=value). Add comparison operators for numeric and string comparisons:

- `key>value` — greater than
- `key<value` — less than
- `key>=value` — greater than or equal
- `key<=value` — less than or equal
- `key!=value` — not equal

Numeric values should be compared numerically (so status>=500 matches 500, 501, 502... not lexicographically). String values fall back to lexicographic comparison.

This is a prerequisite for useful filtering on numeric attributes (HTTP status codes, durations, byte counts, etc.) and will be essential once the pipe-based transformation pipeline (gastrolog-1oep) adds post-aggregation filtering via `where`.

Implementation touches:
- Query parser: recognize comparison operators in key-value expressions
- AST: new node type or extend existing KV node with operator field
- Scanner/filter: runtime comparison evaluation against record attributes
- Index acceleration: range scans on KV index where possible (optional, can start with runtime-only)
- Frontend: syntax highlighting for comparison operators

title.new: Pipeline parser: lexer additions, expression parser, pipe grammar

description.new:
Add pipeline parsing support to the query language. Three tightly coupled pieces:

**Lexer additions:**
- `TokPipe` (`|`) token
- `TokComma` (`,`) token
- Arithmetic operator tokens: `TokPlus`, `TokMinus`, `TokMul`, `TokDiv` (or reuse existing token infrastructure)

**Expression parser** (recursive descent with precedence):
```
expr      = add_expr
add_expr  = mul_expr (("+" | "-") mul_expr)*
mul_expr  = unary_expr (("*" | "/") unary_expr)*
unary_expr = primary_expr
primary_expr = IDENT "(" expr_list ")"   -- function call
             | IDENT                      -- field reference
             | NUMBER                     -- numeric literal
             | STRING                     -- string literal
             | "(" expr ")"              -- grouping
```

**Pipe parser:**
```
pipeline  = filter_expr ("|" pipe_op)*
pipe_op   = stats_op | where_op
stats_op  = "stats" agg_list ("by" group_list)?
agg_list  = agg_expr ("," agg_expr)*
agg_expr  = "count" ("as" IDENT)? | IDENT "(" expr ")" ("as" IDENT)?
group_list = group_expr ("," group_expr)*
group_expr = "bin" "(" DURATION ("," IDENT)? ")" | IDENT
where_op  = "where" filter_expr
```

The existing filter expression parser becomes a callable subroutine — `where` in pipe context reuses it directly.

Contextual keywords: `stats`, `where`, `by`, `as`, `bin` are only special after `|`. `count` is special in `stats` agg list. All are regular barewords in filter phase.

Testable with unit tests: parse query strings, verify AST structure. No execution needed.

description.new:
Evaluate expression trees produced by the pipeline parser against a row (map[string]string).

Given an expression AST node and a row of key-value pairs, produce a result value. Handles:
- Field references: look up key in the row map
- Numeric literals: return as-is
- String literals: return as-is
- Arithmetic (+, -, *, /): evaluate operands, parse as float, compute
- Function calls: dispatch to registered scalar functions

v1 scalar functions:
- `toNumber(field)`: parse string value as float, return error/skip if unparseable

Operator precedence (already encoded in AST structure by the parser):
1. Parentheses
2. *, / (left-to-right)
3. +, - (left-to-right)

The evaluator is context-agnostic — it takes a field resolver function, so it works in both filter phase and pipe phase contexts.

Testable with unit tests: build expression trees, evaluate against known rows, verify results.

description.new:
Implement the stats operator execution engine. Single-pass accumulation over the scanner record stream.

**Core:**
- Maintain `map[groupKey]aggregateState` in memory
- Group key is composite of all `by` field values (including bin() bucket)
- After scanner exhausts, emit result rows (list of maps)

**Aggregate functions (v1):**
- `count`: increment counter
- `avg(expr)`: track sum and count, compute at emit time
- `sum(expr)`: accumulate
- `min(expr)`: track minimum
- `max(expr)`: track maximum
- All use the expression evaluator for their arguments

**Group-by:**
- Field references: look up value in record
- `bin(duration)`: bucket record timestamp (default WriteTS) into intervals
- `bin(duration, field)`: bucket by named timestamp field

**Cardinality cap:**
- Hard limit at N groups (e.g. 10,000)
- Once hit, stop accepting new group keys, keep counting existing ones
- Set `groups_capped: true` in response metadata

**Missing/non-numeric fields:**
- Skip silently. Aggregation functions only consider records where the field exists and parses as a number.

**Gap filling (for bin()):**
- Engine knows query time range and bin size
- Insert zero-rows for empty bins in the output

Testable with synthetic records: feed known data through aggregation, verify output rows, test edge cases (empty input, missing fields, cardinality cap, gap filling).

description.new:
Refactor the frontend query tokenizer classifier from ad-hoc pattern matching to a lightweight recursive descent classifier, and add pipe syntax support.

**Lexer additions:**
- `"pipe"` token kind for `|`
- `"comma"` token kind for `,`
- Arithmetic ops if needed for highlighting

**Classifier refactor:**
Replace the current forward-lookahead pattern matching in `classify()` with a recursive descent classifier that mirrors the grammar:

```
classifyPipeline(tokens):
  classifyFilterExpr(tokens, 0..pipeIndex)
  for each pipe segment:
    classifyPipeOp(tokens, segStart..segEnd)

classifyFilterExpr(tokens, range):
  // walk with state, detect KV triples, operators, etc.

classifyPipeOp(tokens, range):
  keyword → role: pipe-keyword
  switch keyword:
    "stats": classifyStats(rest)
    "where": classifyFilterExpr(rest)
```

Both filter and pipe classifiers use the structured approach. Filter classifier is a refactor of existing logic (same behavior, cleaner implementation).

**New highlight roles:**
- `"pipe"` — the `|` character
- `"pipe-keyword"` — `stats`, `where`
- `"function"` — `count`, `avg`, `sum`, `min`, `max`, `bin`, `toNumber`
- `"comma"` — list separator
- Consider reusing existing role styling where semantically similar

**Validation:**
Update `validate()` to accept pipe syntax without error markers.

Testable independently of backend work.

title.new: Comparison operators (>=, <, etc.) skip value check on sealed chunks

description.new:
When a query uses comparison operators like `status>=400 status<500`, the sealed-chunk index path uses a key-only index lookup (positions where the key exists) but never adds the runtime filter to verify the value comparison. The caller in `buildScannerWithManagers` sees `ok=true` from `applyKeyValueIndex` and skips `keyValueFilter(kv)`, so ALL records with that key are returned regardless of value.

Unsealed chunks always add the runtime filter and produce correct counts. The result is that sealed chunks overcount by the ratio of total-records-with-key to records-matching-the-comparison — typically 2-3x.

The glob filter path (line 534-551) correctly always adds a runtime filter even when the index provides positions. The KV path just missed this for non-eq operators.

**Fix**: always add `keyValueFilter(kv)` when KV filters are present, even when the index provided positions. The index narrows the position set (acceleration), but the runtime filter is still needed to verify comparison values.

**Affected file**: `backend/internal/query/query.go`, lines 554-565.

title.new: Steady real memory growth during repeated pipeline stats queries

description.new:
When running pipeline stats queries with auto-refresh polling (e.g. `error | stats count by level` at 5s intervals), the process's real memory (RSS) grows steadily and does not stabilize. Streaming regular records does not exhibit this behavior.

## Likely causes

Each pipeline query generates significant allocation churn with no caching:

1. **Index files re-read from disk every query**: `applyKeyValueIndex` eagerly opens 8+ index files per sealed chunk via `os.ReadFile` + decode (attr KV, attr key, attr value, kv, kv key, kv value, JSON path, JSON PV). No caching — all re-read and re-decoded per query.

2. **Per-record allocations in tight loop**: `BuildRecordCopy` (raw bytes + attrs map copy) and `RecordToRow` (new map + string conversion) allocate for every record, all short-lived garbage.

3. **macOS MADV_FREE**: Go's scavenger marks freed pages with MADV_FREE, which macOS only reclaims under memory pressure. Pages show as Real Memory in Activity Monitor even when reclaimable.

4. **GC timing vs poll interval**: At 5s auto-refresh, the next query fires before GC finishes scavenging from the previous one.

## Diagnosis

Use pprof (`just pprof`, then `go tool pprof http://localhost:6060/debug/pprof/heap`) to confirm whether it's retained references or GC lag. Force GC with `curl http://localhost:6060/debug/pprof/heap?gc=1` and check if RSS drops.

## Potential fix

Cache immutable index data for sealed chunks. Sealed chunk indexes never change, so reading them once and reusing across queries would eliminate the largest source of allocation churn.

title.new: Pipeline operators: eval, sort, head, parse, rename, fields

description.new:
Streaming row-in/row-out operators beyond stats and where. These don't force materialization and (except sort) are compatible with follow mode.

Operators:
- **eval**: computed fields from expressions (e.g. `eval duration_ms = duration * 1000`). Adds columns, keeps existing ones.
- **sort**: order rows by one or more fields, ascending or descending. Forces materialization (needs all rows to sort). Syntax: `sort field`, `sort -field` (descending).
- **head / tail**: truncate result set to first/last N rows. Syntax: `head 100`, `tail 50`.
- **parse**: query-time field extraction using patterns (grok, dissect, regex named groups). Supplements auto-extraction (KV/logfmt/JSON). Syntax TBD — candidates: `parse /regex with (?P<name>groups)/`, `parse kv delimiter=; sep==`.
- **rename**: rename columns. Syntax: `rename old as new`.
- **fields / project**: select or drop columns. Syntax: `fields field1, field2` (keep only these), `fields - field1` (drop).

All operators follow the table-in/table-out model — each receives a stream of rows (map[string]string) and produces a stream of rows. Pre-stats operators work on record streams; post-stats operators work on aggregate rows.

title.new: Pipeline scalar functions

description.new:
Expression-level functions usable inside stats arguments, eval, and where. The grammar already supports function calls — this is about implementing the evaluator dispatch.

Starting set:
- **toNumber(field)**: string-to-number coercion (essential — extracted fields are strings, numeric aggregation needs explicit coercion for non-obvious cases)
- **len(field)**: string length
- **lower(field) / upper(field)**: case conversion
- **substr(field, start, length)**: substring extraction
- **replace(field, pattern, replacement)**: string replacement
- **trim(field)**: whitespace trimming
- **coalesce(field1, field2, ...)**: first non-missing value
- **if(condition, then, else)**: conditional expression

The expression language is context-agnostic — same functions work in stats, where, and eval contexts. The caller provides field resolution.

title.new: Pipeline aggregation functions

description.new:
Aggregation functions beyond count/sum/avg/min/max.

Candidates:
- **dcount(field)**: distinct count (approximate via HyperLogLog for large cardinalities)
- **p50(field) / p95(field) / p99(field)**: percentiles (approximate via t-digest or DDSketch)
- **median(field)**: alias for p50
- **stddev(field) / variance(field)**: statistical dispersion
- **countif(condition)** / **sumif(field, condition)**: conditional aggregation (Kusto-style `countif`, ClickHouse `-If` combinator)
- **first(field) / last(field)**: first/last value seen (by record order)
- **values(field)**: collect distinct values into a list

Approximate algorithms (HyperLogLog, t-digest) are needed for dcount and percentiles at scale. These can be computed per-chunk and merged for parallel/distributed execution.

description.new:
Pre-stats pipeline operators (eval, where, sort, fields, rename) and the raw operator resolve fields directly from rec.Attrs, which only contains explicit metadata set at ingest time. They do not extract KV pairs, JSON fields, or logfmt pairs from the raw message text.

In contrast, the aggregation layer (stats) uses RecordToRow() in aggregate.go, which calls tokenizer.CombinedExtract() and tokenizer.ExtractJSON() to extract fields from the raw message, then overlays Attrs on top. This means stats can aggregate on extracted fields (e.g. duration, status, bytes) but eval/where/sort/raw cannot see them.

The fix is to route field resolution in pre-stats record operators through RecordToRow() (or an equivalent extraction step) so all pipeline operators have the same field visibility as stats.

Affected code:
- backend/internal/query/pipeline_ops.go — applyRecordWhere, applyRecordEval, applyRecordSort, applyRecordFields, applyRecordRename all operate on rec.Attrs directly
- backend/internal/query/pipeline.go — recordsToTable() only iterates rec.Attrs for column discovery
- backend/internal/query/aggregate.go — RecordToRow() is the correct extraction path that should be reused

title.new: Expired token errors shown as toasts when tab regains focus after being backgrounded

description.new:
When the browser tab loses focus, the proactive token refresh timer gets throttled by the browser. The token expires while backgrounded, and when the tab regains focus, requests fail with `[unauthenticated] invalid token: parse token: token has invalid claims: token is expired` — which surfaces as error toasts.

The `unauthInterceptor` in `client.ts` already handles refresh-then-retry for regular requests, but the streaming hooks (`useFollow`, `useSearch`) catch `Unauthenticated` errors and call their error callbacks (which trigger toasts) before or alongside the interceptor's retry path. These errors should be handled silently — refresh the token and retry without surfacing anything to the user.

title.new: Empty inputs with placeholder defaults rejected instead of falling back to defaults

description.new:
When a user clears an input field that shows a placeholder default (e.g. chatterbox minInterval with placeholder "100ms"), the frontend sends an empty string in the params map. Some backend factories only check key existence (`if v, ok := params["key"]; ok`) and try to parse the empty string, which fails with errors like `invalid minInterval "": time: invalid duration ""`.

**Root cause**: Mismatch between frontend (sends `{"minInterval": ""}`) and backend (assumes presence means non-empty). Some factories already handle this correctly — `tail`, `docker`, and `metrics` check `if v != ""` before parsing — but `chatterbox` does not.

**Scope — all inputs with placeholder defaults need review**:

Ingester params:
- Chatterbox: `minInterval`, `maxInterval`, `hostCount`, `serviceCount` — BROKEN
- Tail: `poll_interval` — safe (checks `v != ""`)
- Docker: `poll_interval` — safe
- Metrics: `interval` — safe
- OTLP: `http_addr`, `grpc_addr`
- Kafka: `sasl_mechanism`, `sasl_user`, `sasl_password`

Config forms with placeholders:
- Rotation policies: `maxBytes`, `maxRecords`, `maxAge`, `cron`
- Retention policies: `maxAge`, `maxBytes`, `maxChunks`
- Server config: `tokenDuration`, `refreshTokenDuration`, `queryTimeout`, `maxFollowDuration`

**Fix approach**: Both layers — backend factories should treat empty strings the same as absent keys (defensive), and frontend should strip empty-string params before sending (clean).

description.new:
The frontend currently approximates field extraction with a `key=value` regex (`extractKVPairs`), but the backend runs richer extractors (KV, logfmt, access log, JSON) via `tokenizer.CombinedExtract`. This means fields like `remote_host`, `method`, `path` from access log lines never appear in autocomplete or the sidebar.

More broadly, the frontend duplicates query validation logic (tokenizer, keyword sets, structural checks) that the backend's parser is the source of truth for. These should converge.

## Pipeline-aware field context

Each pipeline operator can change the available field set. An `eval` adds fields, `rename` replaces them, `fields -` drops them, `lookup` adds suffixed fields, and `stats` replaces the entire schema with aggregation columns. Autocomplete suggestions need to reflect the field set *at the cursor position in the pipeline* — not just the raw record fields. This means the backend needs to simulate the pipeline up to the cursor and report what fields would exist at that point.

## Proposed RPCs

1. **`GetFields`** — Given a query expression + time range + pipeline position, sample matching records, simulate operators up to the cursor, and return the resulting field set. Replaces the frontend's `aggregateFields` + `extractKVPairs`.

2. **`ValidateQuery`** — Given a partial or complete expression + cursor position, return parse errors and contextual suggestions. Replaces the frontend's tokenizer-based validation and could power autocomplete directly.

With reverse=true, this means only the most recent ~100 records are aggregated, making stats queries appear to only read from the latest unsealed chunk. The timechart scan path already clears this limit (q.Limit=0), but the main RunPipeline path did not.

Reverse DNS lookup table
description:
Support reverse DNS lookups in the `lookup` pipeline operator. Maps IP addresses to hostnames via PTR record queries.

Example: `| lookup rdns src_ip` adds `src_ip_hostname`.

Key considerations:
- Network calls during query execution — needs aggressive caching (LRU or TTL-based) to avoid latency blowup
- Consider a bounded concurrency pool for DNS queries to avoid flooding the resolver
- Cache should persist across queries (not per-query) to amortize cost
- Timeout per lookup to prevent stalling on unresponsive DNS servers
- No external file dependency — uses the system resolver

Fix eval string literals, input performance, pipeline defaults, and Enter key behavior
description:
Several fixes from the DNS lookup branch work:

1. **String literal parsing in eval** — quoted strings like "8.8.8.8" were parsed as field references (FieldRef) instead of string literals (StringLit). Added Quoted flag to lexer tokens so parsePrimaryPipeExpr produces StringLit for quoted strings. This caused eval assignments to silently produce MissingValue, breaking downstream lookup operators.

2. **Input performance** — the query input was extremely sluggish because validation and pipeline field RPCs triggered synchronous re-renders of the massive SearchView component. Fixed by using useDeferredValue(draft) for all expensive computations, moving cursor tracking to a ref, wrapping both RPC hooks in startTransition, and deferring tokenization in QueryInput.

3. **Unterminated pipeline defaults to raw** — pipelines with operators but no explicit visualizer (stats/timechart/raw) now default to table output instead of returning a broken filter view.

4. **Enter always executes query** — autocomplete suggestions are now accepted only with Tab, never with Enter. Previously Enter would accept the first autocomplete suggestion instead of executing the query.

Auto-format pipe queries and format button
description:
Add auto-formatting for pipe queries in the query bar:

- Typing | auto-inserts a newline before the pipe for readability
- Add a format button (flower icon for 'pretty printing') that reformats existing queries with each pipe segment on its own line
- Extract all inline SVGs from QueryBar into shared icon components in icons.tsx

New icons: HistoryIcon, BookmarkIcon, FormatIcon, HelpCircleIcon, SearchIcon, XIcon, PlayIcon, StopIcon, PlanIcon

Improve pipeline operator parser test coverage
description:
The pipeline parser tests are thin — mostly one happy-path test per operator and a basic error table. Bulk up coverage:

- Negative number handling for head/tail/slice (parse the minus, reject as non-positive)
- Frontend tokenizer parity for the same cases
- More edge cases per operator: boundary values, chained operators, whitespace variations, etc.

This also includes the fix for head/tail/slice not recognizing a leading minus as part of the number (previously errored with 'got -' instead of 'must be positive').

Pipeline without visualizer should return records, not raw table
description:
Currently any pipeline with operators (eval, rename, fields, lookup, head, tail, etc.) but no explicit visualizer (stats/timechart/raw) forces the result into a raw table via recordsToTable(). This means the normal log viewer (expandable rows, sidebar fields, context) is lost.

The fix: when a pipeline has pre-ops but no stats/timechart/raw, return PipelineResult{Records} instead of PipelineResult{Table}. The search limit should be reapplied so the pipeline doesn't try to return unbounded results.

This makes 'raw' an explicit opt-in for table mode, while the default pipeline result is the familiar log view with transformed records.

GeoIP lookup table (MaxMind MMDB)
description:
Support GeoIP lookups via MaxMind's GeoLite2-City MMDB file. Example: `| lookup geoip src_ip` adds `src_ip_country`, `src_ip_city`, `src_ip_lat`, `src_ip_lon`.

Configuration: `geoip_db` path in server config pointing to the MMDB file. If set and the file exists, the `geoip` lookup table is available in pipelines. Hot-reload via `atomic.Pointer` swap when the file changes on disk.

Uses the same mmap-friendly MMDB reader pattern planned for ASN lookups. Users are responsible for obtaining the MMDB file (e.g. via MaxMind's `geoipupdate` tool).

Toast/notification system for backend feedback
description: General-purpose UI notification system so the backend can surface errors, warnings, and confirmations to the user. Currently many operations fail silently (GeoIP load failures, config reload errors, job failures) and the user gets no feedback. Needs a toast/snackbar component that can be triggered from API responses, background events, and server-sent errors.

Validate GeoIP MMDB path on save
description: When saving the lookups config, validate the MMDB path server-side (file exists, valid MMDB format) and return the result immediately. On success, return metadata (database type, build date, record count). On failure, return a specific error (file not found, not a valid MMDB file, permission denied). The frontend shows the result inline on the settings form so the user knows immediately whether their path is correct.
